titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Galerie Jacques Benador Archive
titlestmt.author: by Rosemary K. J. Davis

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:04

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Galerie Jacques Benador Archive, which spans 1932-2015, contains writings, correspondence, exhibition catalogs, printed material, artworks, and other papers related to Jacques Benador, the D. Benador Gallery, and the Jacques Benador Gallery. Jacques Benador's personal papers—which include a large number of photographs--make up the bulk of the collection, documenting Benador's personal and professional relationships with artists and critics of the postwar European avant-garde, as well as events at both galleries he oversaw. Items of note in the collection include multiple manuscript versions of Lucio Fontana's first Spatialist Manifesto, signed first editions of Fontana's Manifesto Bianco in Italian and Spanish, original artwork by Pierre Alechinsky, Hans Bellmer, Max Ernst, Pierre Tal-Coat, Bram van de Velde, Wols, and others.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 13 (digital media): Restricted fragile material. Access copies of digital files may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Box 14 (long-playing records): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. Catalogs and Invitations, 1948-2015. II. Artist Monographs and Publications, 1946-2006. III. Personal Papers and Business Records, 1932-2014. IV. Musical Recordings, 1980-1993. V. Artwork, 1952-1972.

bioghist.head: Jacques Benador Gallery
bioghist.p: In 1928, Galerie D. Benador was founded in Geneva, Switzerland by David Benador (1893-1974) and his brother Charles (1896-1943). The gallery specialized in works in by old masters, Impressionists, 19th century Barbizon and Swiss school. In 1943, David's son, Jacques Benador (1923-2010), assumed leadership of the gallery and introduced Modern and Contemporary art to the gallery's repertoire. Jacques Benador cultivated relationships with contemporary artists—particularly ones involved with surrealism and abstract art. Jacques, who had a special interest in illustrated books both as a noted publisher and as a collector, also oversaw the production of exhibition catalogs (which were designed to be held in one's hand) that often included a specially prepared text, written by well-known authors; some catalogs also included an original print (or a poster) designed by artists for the first fifty copies of the publishing run. In 1973, Jacques opened his own gallery located in the old city of Geneva under the name "Galerie Jacques Benador". After the passing of David Benador, Jacques Benador—along with his wife, Stella--supervised and directed Galerie D. Benador for several years. Galerie Jacques Benador closed its doors in 2010.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Galerie Jacques Benador Archive. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.
This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Galerie Jacques Benador Archive, which spans 1932-2015, contains writings, correspondence, exhibition catalogs, printed material, artworks, and other papers related to Jacques Benador, the D. Benador Gallery, and the Jacques Benador Gallery. Jacques Benador's personal papers—which include a large number of photographs--make up the bulk of the collection, documenting Benador's personal and professional relationships with artists and critics of the postwar European avant-garde, as well as events at both galleries he oversaw. Items of note in the collection include multiple manuscript versions of Lucio Fontana's first Spatialist Manifesto, signed first editions of Fontana's Manifesto Bianco in Italian and Spanish, original artwork by Pierre Alechinsky, Hans Bellmer, Max Ernst, Pierre Tal-Coat, Bram van de Velde, Wols, and others.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Galerie Jacques Benador Archive is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains invitations, catalogs, and printed material related to artist exhibitions at venues including the Jacques Benador Gallery. Similar materials can also be found in Series III, Personal Papers and Business Records.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material within this series maintains the original organization found at time of acquisition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains artist monographs and publications, including several documenting the work of artists represented by the Jacques Benador Gallery.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material within this series have been organized into seven subseries: File I-III, File IV, File V, File VI, File VII, File VIII, Uncollected Notes. This arrangement reflects the original order of materials at time of acquisition, including the maintenance of Jacques Benador's filing system for his personal papers, which involved keeping items in bound volumes of annotated plastic page covers. For preservation purposes, a majority of items were removed from these page covers and photocopies were made to retain a record of Mr. Benador's annotations. These preservation photocopies are included in folders with the original materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains materials related to Jacques Benador, the Jacques Benador Gallery, and events, publications, and ephemera related to the Gallery. Materials include correspondence, notes, photographs, documentation of exhibitions, and various personal and professional ephemera.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials contain originals and photocopies of photographs, correspondence between Jacques Benador and artists, and pieces of ephemera and printed material related to the Jacques Benador Gallery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This limited edition catalog was designed specifically for the Galerie D. Benador, contains an original photograph by Hans Bellmer, and was the personal copy of Jacques Benador.
